stream_context.summary: Kaze fine-tunes ambient SFX, tweaks overworld geometry, fixes a long-standing audio crackle and hunts a RAM-related crash while livestreaming work on Return to Yoshi’s Island.

development_findings.summary: Added numerous ambient sound effects (elevator, fire, shy-guy, roller-coaster) to the carnival area to make the world feel alive.
development_findings.quote: Just adding a couple sound effects makes it feel so much better.

development_findings.summary: Implemented a fix that removes the persistent audio crackling heard in previous builds.
development_findings.quote: I made the most important fix in history yesterday – the audio crackling is gone.

development_findings.summary: Started using a new UV-mapping tool that speeds up environment texturing.
development_findings.quote: Man, this new UV mapping tool is great.

development_findings.summary: Project status: 15 courses are complete; only three overworld sections remain to finish the first art pass, putting the project in its final stretch.
development_findings.quote: We finished 15 courses now and now we’re just finishing the overworld, so we are like the final stretch.

development_findings.summary: Game scope is roughly four times the size of Super Mario 64 yet still runs on real N64 hardware.
development_findings.quote: It is a gigantic game, probably four times the size of the original, and it all runs on real hardware.

development_findings.summary: Levels can exhaust the 8 MB limit; Kaze frees RAM by deleting unused actors (e.g., comet, UFO platform) and exporting levels without hidden bleed-in lines.
development_findings.quote: We’re out of memory in this level, so let me just make up some memory by killing unused assets.

development_findings.summary: Adopted Sauraen’s custom F3DX3 microcode, increasing fixed-point vertex precision eight-fold with no performance cost, reducing geometry wobble on N64.
development_findings.quote: F3DX3 has increased the precision eightfold… so the precision issue is going to be much smaller.

development_findings.summary: Planned Wing Cap level was accidentally omitted; design now places it above ‘Koopa with Koff’ area, entered via a hotel room.
development_findings.quote: Wait, the wing cap level… we indeed do not have the wing cap planned in… The hotel room. Right. That makes sense.

development_findings.summary: Shipyard concept: a baby Yoshi jumps on Mario’s head demanding the unfinished flying ship; once the player has X stars, a cut-scene launches the ship to a new area.
development_findings.quote: There is a baby Yoshi that really can’t wait for the ship to get finished… when you have enough stars, you jump on and the cutscene… flies off.

development_findings.summary: Replaced an unpopular ‘Pokey carrying balls’ star with a roller-coaster objective to improve fun.
development_findings.quote: What’s so bad about the Pokey carrying the balls around?… Plus you get to ride the roller-coaster – how cool is that?

development_findings.summary: Project64 remains the primary emulator despite flaws because alternatives have worse issues; Kaze routinely tests on real hardware to validate fixes.
development_findings.quote: Kind of every emulator that exists right now has some huge issues… Project 64 has the smallest out of the bunch.

context_findings.summary: Believes ‘developing video games is suffering,’ echoing a Buddhist view that life is suffering.
context_findings.quote: Developing video games is suffering. The Buddhists had it right when they said that life is suffering.

context_findings.summary: Moved to Canada in 2021 and now lives with his wife Zeina and their baby.
context_findings.quote: Yep, I live here with my wife and a little baby actually.

context_findings.summary: Holds a separate full-time job as a game programmer (not designer) working daily in Unreal Engine 5 under NDA.
context_findings.quote: My real job is not a game design job. It’s a game programmer job and I can’t tell you what I’m making without breaking NDA.

context_findings.summary: Limits streams to about two hours and occasionally schedules beach time with Zeina for work-life balance.
context_findings.quote: My stream is probably going to be exactly two hours… me and Zeina, we want to go to the beach still.

context_findings.summary: Self-reflective about communication style, worrying he may sound like Jordan Peterson when he asks clarifying questions.
context_findings.quote: My biggest fear is that people are going to accuse me of talking like Jordan Peterson.

context_findings.summary: Initiated talks with a merch company to possibly produce plush ‘Kaze teddy bears.’
context_findings.quote: I was actually in talk with a merch company today, and if you’re lucky, we can organize those.

biobak.summary: Re-textured the pirate-ship sail to look more ‘pirate-y’ after earlier feedback.
biobak.quote: I’m not sure if Biobak completely replaced the sail texture… but this looks a lot more pirate-y now.

biobak.summary: Provides ongoing visual feedback; Kaze greeted him and referenced earlier collaborative work on treelines.

zeina.summary: Off-stream partner feedback; she reacted positively to new overworld shortcut piece.
zeina.quote: She loves me – she loves me not.

zeina.summary: Personal dynamic: Kaze ends stream early to go to the beach with Zeina, highlighting work-life balance.

key_stories.title: Crackling Audio Vanquished
key_stories.summary: A long-standing crackle plagued the game’s soundtrack. Kaze experimented with audio sample handling and finally eliminated the noise the day before this stream.
key_stories.challenge: Persistent audio crackling in builds and streams.
key_stories.process: Investigated sample deletion and audio pipeline; applied fixes to sample handling.
key_stories.outcome: Crackling is gone; celebrated on stream.
key_stories.key_quote: I made the most important fix in history yesterday – the audio crackling is gone.

key_stories.title: RAM Crash in the UFO Level
key_stories.summary: One overworld area crashed due to memory overflow. By removing unused objects (comet, UFO platform) and optimizing export flags, Kaze regained stability.
key_stories.challenge: Level crashed, potentially due to framebuffer and 8 MB RAM exhaustion.
key_stories.process: Profiled RAM, deleted unused actors, exported level without bleed-in lines.
key_stories.outcome: Level loads without crashing; memory headroom restored.
key_stories.key_quote: It was a RAM issue – I need to fix this for Sauraen actually.

key_stories.title: Precision Breakthrough with F3DX3
key_stories.summary: Vertex wobbles on real N64 hardware prompted adoption of Sauraen’s custom microcode, multiplying fixed-point precision eightfold at no cost.
key_stories.challenge: Geometry jitter and depth issues on hardware due to limited vertex precision.
key_stories.process: Tested Sauraen’s F3DX3 microcode that removes Nintendo’s wasteful operation.
key_stories.outcome: Visual stability improved; Kaze demonstrates clean visuals on console.
key_stories.key_quote: F3DX3 has increased the precision eightfold without any cost.
